intro: Antirrhinum siculum var. typicum, commonly known as the Sicilian snapdragon, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Plantaginaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, tubular, red or orange flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and produces clusters of showy flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branched. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements.
